message.content:
cs.IT, cs.NI, cs.SI, cs.DS, cs.CC 

Reasoning: 
1. cs.IT (Information Theory) - The paper deals with a communication problem and derives a necessary and sufficient condition for a linear coding scheme to satisfy the demands of all the receivers in a given BNSI network. It also provides lower bounds and upper bounds on the optimal codelength and constructions of linear coding schemes based on linear error correcting codes. 
2. cs.NI (Networking and Internet Architecture) - The paper discusses the application of the BNSI problem in the re-transmission phase of downlink networks. 
3. cs.SI (Social and Information Networks) - The paper represents BNSI problems as bipartite graphs and uses this representation to classify the family of problems where linear coding provides bandwidth savings compared to uncoded transmission. 
4. cs.DS (Data Structures and Algorithms) - The paper provides a simple algorithm to determine if a given BNSI network belongs to the family of problems where linear coding provides an advantage over uncoded transmission. 
5. cs.CC (Computational Complexity) - The paper does not explicitly deal with computational complexity, but the problem of determining if a given BNSI network belongs to the family of problems where linear coding provides an advantage over uncoded transmission can be seen as a computational problem.
